title: I do not understand “rape culture”
summary:
Key ideas:
- The author (Scott) is confused and skeptical of the term "rape culture"
- Scott discusses five claims involved in "rape culture"
- Scott argues against all of these claims, stating that they are diametrically wrong
- The concept of a "rape culture" is invalid because American culture fixates largely on rape-related matters.
- The comparatively low attention paid to Syrian Civil War as compared to Steubenville rape case is an example.
- Cognitive bias applies to every type of crime.

Key learnings:
- Scott argues that society treats rape as a special kind of evil, worse than other crimes
- The criminal justice system does not have a higher burden of proof in rape trials than in other trials
- People giving well-intentioned but stupid advice to rape survivors is not unique to rape
- People may overemphasize certain topics or issues over others, creating a culture of fixation rather than disregarding sensitive topics such as rape.
- Cognitive bias regarding crime may be a factor.

Key questions:
- What are some good proposals for avoiding the difficulty of getting rape cases to trial?
- Is sexual objectification of women causing the latent condoning/promotion of rape?
- What does our fixation on rape-related topics say about our culture?
- Is the concept of a "rape culture" adequately addressing how our culture views sexual assault?
- To what extent are cognitive biases affecting modern discussions surrounding crime?
